title: Multiple Chinese entities provide second batch of anti-epidemic materials to the Central African Republic in June 2020 (Linked to Project ID#92974)
description: On June 11, 2020, the Chinese government provided a second batch of anti-epidemic materials to the Central African Republic. These materials were sent in response to a notice from the Central African Republic that test kits were running out in Africa. This donation, therefore, included test kits and other anti-epidemic materials. In addition to the Chinese government and the Chinese embassy in the Central African Republic, contributions to the donation came from the Chinese People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries, China Railway 11th Bureau (a subsidiary of China Railway Construction) , and Gezhouba Group. The China Railway 11th Bureau's contribution consisted of at least 5,000 nucleic acid testing kits. The contributions by the other entities and the monetary value of these donations are unknown.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation at Bangui International Airport located in Bangui, the capital of the Central African Republic.  Central African President Faustin-Archange Touadéra, China’s Ambassador to Central Africa, Chen Dong, the Central African Minister of Health, the Minister of Economic Cooperation, and a WHO Representative in Central Africa attended the ceremony.  According to the Chinese Embassy in the Central African Republic, this is a second batch of materials provided by the Chinese government. Details on the first batch are provided in Project ID#92974.
staff_comments: 1. Because the only known amount of supplies donated is 5,000 nucleic acid testing kits, AidData uses the unit amount value for these kits to estimate a total transaction amount for this donation. The value of these 5,000 nucleic acid kits is an estimated $48,650.00 USD.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Multiple Chinese entities provide second batch of anti-epidemic materials to the Central African Republic in June 2020 (Linked to Project ID#92974)

# Description
On June 11, 2020, the Chinese government provided a second batch of anti-epidemic materials to the Central African Republic. These materials were sent in response to a notice from the Central African Republic that test kits were running out in Africa. This donation, therefore, included test kits and other anti-epidemic materials. In addition to the Chinese government and the Chinese embassy in the Central African Republic, contributions to the donation came from the Chinese People's Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries, China Railway 11th Bureau (a subsidiary of China Railway Construction) , and Gezhouba Group. The China Railway 11th Bureau's contribution consisted of at least 5,000 nucleic acid testing kits. The contributions by the other entities and the monetary value of these donations are unknown.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation at Bangui International Airport located in Bangui, the capital of the Central African Republic.  Central African President Faustin-Archange Touadéra, China’s Ambassador to Central Africa, Chen Dong, the Central African Minister of Health, the Minister of Economic Cooperation, and a WHO Representative in Central Africa attended the ceremony.  According to the Chinese Embassy in the Central African Republic, this is a second batch of materials provided by the Chinese government. Details on the first batch are provided in Project ID#92974.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies for epidemic response, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Anti-epidemic materials including test kits, healthcare focus, no energy-related components

title: Chinese government provides first batch of anti-epidemic supplies to the Central African Republic in May 2020 (Linked to Project ID#92889, #93597, #93598)
description: On May 20, 2020, the Chinese government provided the first batch of anti-epidemic supplies to the Central African Republic. The monetary value of this donation is unknown. This is the first of two batches of anti-epidemic materials provided by the Chinese government to the Central African Republic. The second batch was provided in June of 2020 and the details of that donation are outlined in Project ID#92889.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation at the Presidential Palace of the Central African Republic. The President of the Central African Republic, Central African Minister of State and Chief of Staff of the Presidential Office, the Presidential Press Advisor, the Presidential Political Advisor, the Minister of National Defense, the Minister of Economic Planning and International Cooperation, the Commander of the National Gendarmeria, the Superintendent of the police, and Chinese Ambassador Chen Dong attended the ceremony.  This handover ceremony also included the handover of supplies from the Jack Ma Foundation, a donation from the Fujian Police Institute, (project ID #93597) and a donation from the Chinese Embassy (project ID #93598).
combined_text:

This handover ceremony also included the handover of supplies from the Jack Ma Foundation, a donation from the Fujian Police Institute, (project ID #93597) and a donation from the Chinese Embassy (project ID #93598).

title: Chinese government provides anti-epidemic materials to the Central African Republic in March 2020
description: On March 23, 2020, the Chinese government provided anti-epidemic materials to the Central African Republic. These materials consisted of 4,000 gloves, 3,000 masks, 150 coveralls and 100 protective glasses. These materials will be distributed to various health centers for COVID-19 response efforts. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation in Bangui, Central Africa. At the ceremony, China’s Ambassador to the Central African Republic, Chen Dong, handed over the materials to the President of the Central African Republic, Faustin-Archange Touadéra. The Ambassador of France,  The Central African Minister of Health Pierre Somsé, Éric Gérard, and others also attended the ceremony.
staff_comments: 1. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese government provides anti-epidemic materials to the Central African Republic in March 2020

# Description
On March 23, 2020, the Chinese government provided anti-epidemic materials to the Central African Republic. These materials consisted of 4,000 gloves, 3,000 masks, 150 coveralls and 100 protective glasses. These materials will be distributed to various health centers for COVID-19 response efforts. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation in Bangui, Central Africa. At the ceremony, China’s Ambassador to the Central African Republic, Chen Dong, handed over the materials to the President of the Central African Republic, Faustin-Archange Touadéra. The Ambassador of France,  The Central African Minister of Health Pierre Somsé, Éric Gérard, and others also attended the ceremony.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies for COVID-19 response, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Anti-epidemic materials (gloves, masks, coveralls, protective glasses) for health centers, COVID-19 response focus

title: Chinese government provides electoral and anti-epidemic materials to the Central African Republic in September 2020 (Linked to Project ID# 86522)
description: On September 15, 2020, the Chinese government provided electoral and anti-epidemic materials to the Central African Republic. These materials included desktop computers, laptops, walkie-talkies, generators, masks, gloves, and forehead thermometers. These supplies are valued at around CFA 800 million.   A handover ceremony was held for this donation at the Presidential Palace of Central Africa. At the ceremony, China’s Ambassador to the Central African Republic, Chen Dong, provided the materials to the President of the Central African Republic, Faustin-Archange Touadéra. The Prime Minister of Central Africa, the Central African Ministers of Planning, Health, and Land Management, and the Chief of Staff of the Presidential Office also attended the ceremony.  This project is the first batch of electoral materials provided by China to the Central African Republic. The second batch is detailed in Project ID#86522.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER MULTISECTOR

# Title
Chinese government provides electoral and anti-epidemic materials to the Central African Republic in September 2020 (Linked to Project ID# 86522)

# Description
On September 15, 2020, the Chinese government provided electoral and anti-epidemic materials to the Central African Republic. These materials included desktop computers, laptops, walkie-talkies, generators, masks, gloves, and forehead thermometers. These supplies are valued at around CFA 800 million.   A handover ceremony was held for this donation at the Presidential Palace of Central Africa. At the ceremony, China’s Ambassador to the Central African Republic, Chen Dong, provided the materials to the President of the Central African Republic, Faustin-Archange Touadéra. The Prime Minister of Central Africa, the Central African Ministers of Planning, Health, and Land Management, and the Chief of Staff of the Presidential Office also attended the ceremony.  This project is the first batch of electoral materials provided by China to the Central African Republic. The second batch is detailed in Project ID#86522.
justification: Project focuses on providing electoral and health-related materials without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Electoral materials and anti-epidemic supplies including computers, communication devices, and medical equipment

title: Fujian Police Institute provides anti-epidemic supplies to the Central African Republic in May 2020 (Linked to Project ID# 92974)
description: On May 20, 2020, the Fujian Police Institute of China provided anti-epidemic supplies to the Central African Republic. These supplies will be used for COVID-19 prevention efforts in the Central African Republic. These supplies included 5,000 nose masks, 20 coveralls, 20 goggles and 8 frontal guns. The monetary value of this donation is unknown.  A handover ceremony was held for this donation at the Presidential Palace of the Central African Republic. The President of the Central African Republic, Central African Minister of State and Chief of Staff of the Presidential Office, the Presidential Press Advisor, the Presidential Political Advisor, the Minister of National Defense, the Minister of Economic Planning and International Cooperation, the Commander of the National Gendarmeria, the Superintendent of the police, and Chinese Ambassador Chen Dong attended the ceremony.  This handover ceremony also included the handover of supplies from the Chinese government. The details of that donation is outlined in Project ID’s #92974.
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.

title: Fujian Provincial Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries provides masks and thermometers to the Prime Minister’s office in August 2020 (Linked to #92941 and #95291)
description: On August 3, 2020, the Red Cross Society of China, the Fujian Provincial Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries, and the Zhangzhou Public Security Bureau of the Fujian Province jointly provided anti-epidemic materials to the Central African Republic. The Red Cross Society provided five ventilators to the Central African government (captured via #92941). The Fujian Provincial Association for Friendship with Foreign Countries provided 4,000 masks and 40 forehead thermometers to the Prime Minister’s office (captured via ##95290). The Zhangzhou Public Security Bureau of the Fujian Province provided 10,000 masks to the Central African Ministry of Internal Affairs and Public Security (captured via #95291).  A handover ceremony was held for this donation at the office of the Prime Minister of the Central African Republic. Chinese Ambassador Chen Dong, representatives of the Prime Minister of the Central African Republic, the Minister of Health, and the Director of the Ministry of Internal Affairs and Public Security attended the ceremony.
staff_comments: 1. AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogs from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.

title: MOFCOM suspends debt service payments from Government of Central African Republic in 2020
description: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). As part of DSSI, China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) and the Government of Central African Republic signed a debt suspension agreement during calendar year 2020 (most likely between May 2020 and July 2020).   Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal payments due between May 2020 and December 2020 under one or more interest-free loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount is $875,000. Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
staff_comments: 1. AidData assumes that the same basic terms and conditions that governed China Eximbank’s DSSI (debt suspension) agreement with other governments also applied to the DSSI agreement that MOFCOM signed with the Government of Central African Republic. Illustrative DSSI agreements can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/huwa695j3w9hwig/DSSI%20Agreement%20for%20Kyrgyz%20Republic.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/67n1oq44it27kvu/3.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20GCL%20Other%20Projects.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/n69i598f0fg7s80/6.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20PBC%20C2.pdf?dl=0. 2. The total suspension amount under the 2020 debt suspension agreement is unknown.  However, according to the IMF, 'India, China, and Saudi Arabia participated in the G20 Debt Service Suspension Initiative to C.A.R., along with Kuwait for an amount of US$ 3.5 million from May to December 2020’, so for the time being AidData assumes that all four creditors suspended an equal amount of principal and interest ($875,000 each).  3. The specific MOFCOM loan that was subject to the suspension agreement may have been a 2015 loan worth $38,550,389.60 (see https://www.dropbox.com/s/2sw4f7gluxa52fk/DRS%20Official%20Commitments%20from%20China%20Through%202021.xlsx?dl=0). This issue requires further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
MOFCOM suspends debt service payments from Government of Central African Republic in 2020

# Description
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI). As part of DSSI, China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) and the Government of Central African Republic signed a debt suspension agreement during calendar year 2020 (most likely between May 2020 and July 2020).   Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal payments due between May 2020 and December 2020 under one or more interest-free loan agreements. The total estimated suspension amount is $875,000. Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
justification: Project involves debt service suspension and financial arrangements without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Debt suspension agreement, focus on financial obligations and COVID-19 response spending
